name: Phileas Dazeley-Gaist
bio_html: Phileas is a human ecologist, creative technologist, and developer at Wolfram Research, working at the crossroads between human ecology and complexity science. Their work spans agent-based modeling, ecological and environmental systems modeling, GIS, and digital humanities, with a special focus on interdisciplinary, human-ecological projects.

name: Travis Holmes
bio_html: With previous experience in international education, law enforcement, military service, and higher education program management, Travis’ interests involve the application of complexity science theories and principles to better understand how information (at multiple scales) impacts collective human decision making. Examples include social collective action, the evolution of social and cultural institutions, or the construction of epistemic architectures. Methodologically, he is interested in the use of ethnographic data and narratives to facilitate the design of evidence-based models for positive social intervention. He holds a B.A. in Psychology and Criminal Justice from Virginia Commonwealth University, an M.A. in International Studies from the University of San Francisco, and a doctorate in International Studies from Old Dominion University.

name: Arhan Vora
bio_html: Arhan is a Mathematical Biologist and Complex Systems scientist at the Institut des Sciences de l'Evolution, Montpellier. He is interested in understanding Ecology and Evolution through a complex systems lens. His work spans the collective behaviour of mixed species flocks and stochastic models for the evolution of antibiotic resistance in E. Coli.

name: Ariel Salgado
bio_html: Ariel Salgado is a young researcher whose main interest lie on Complexity, Urban Systems, Quantitative Geography and Social Dynamics. Currently based at the Calculus Institute at the University of Buenos Aires, he is an Associate Professor at the Computer Science Department at the University of Buenos Aires and at the Digital Systems Department at the Technological Institute of Buenos Aires, in Argentina. He has a PhD in Physics from the University of Buenos Aires, and a Master's degree in Technological Physics from the Balseiro Institute. He participated in the Complexity Global School 2024 as a student, and in the next iteration as a Peer-Mentor.

name: Emmy Tither
bio_html: Emmy is a PhD Candidate in Informatics at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, studying information policy and armed conflict.

name: Swathi Nachiar Manivannan
bio_html: Swathi is a PhD student at the Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at Yale University. Her research focuses on understanding the mechanisms and factors that influence the capacity of (pathogenic) microbes to adaptively evolve (i.e., their evolvability), and what this means for the spread and control of infectious disease outbreaks. More broadly, she is also interested in thinking about the importance of context-dependence in evolutionary biology, both in terms of how context-dependence manifests in our understanding of evolution and the historical and contemporary contexts in which evolutionary biologists develop and engage with theory.

name: Eider L. PÃ©rez-Ordoyo Bellido
bio_html: Coming from Physics and Neuroscience, she has found her comfiest place in the Complexity Science community. Their current work is in Computational Neuroscience, but she envisions herself working in projects regarding History and Philosophy of Science, Science of Science, Linguistics, Epistemology and other. They have too many interests to fit in a small bio, that's why Complexity Coffee is a great match for her curiosity.
